Summons Issued as to Teri Maxymillian, Michael Hogan, Donald Sawyer. (nas, ) (Entered: 03/10/2009)

REPORT−RECOMMENDATIONS and ORDER: RECOMMENDED that Defendants' motion for summary judgment (Dkt. No. 37 ) be GRANTED IN PART AND DENIED IN PART. Recommend that the Court grant Defendants' motion and dismiss the following claims: (1) the free exercise and RLUIPA claims regarding the use of bowls and utensils; (2) the free exercise and RLUIPA claims regarding CNYPC's practice of serving fish on Fridays; (3) any Establishment Clause claim regarding CNYPC's practice of serving fish on Fridays; (4) the due process claim; (5) the Eighth Amendment claim; and (6) all claims against Defendant Hogan. RECOMMENDED that Plaintiff's motion for summary judgment (Dkt. No. 33 ) be DENIED. RECOMMENDED that the following claims survive the pending motions: (1) the free exercise and RLUIPA claims regarding the lack of Al Jumu'ah services at CNYPC; (2) the free exercise and RLUIPA claims regarding the lack of a Halal menu at CNYPC; (3) the claim regarding CNYPC's requirement that Plaintiff attend classes on Fridays; and (4) the claim that Defendants denied Plaintiff sacred foods on holidays. The parties should be prepared, in further proceedings, to fully brief whether the legitimate Penological interest or the compelling government interest test should be applied to this case. Objections to R&R due by 1/6/2011 Case Review Deadline 1/13/2011. Signed by Magistrate Judge George H. Lowe on 12/22/10. {r&r and copies of the cited cases served via regular mail on plaintiff}(nas ) (Entered: 12/23/2010)

DECISION AND ORDER: The 42 Report and Recommendations is accepted and adopted in all respects. ORDERED that plaintiff's 33 Motion for Summary Judgment is DENIED. ORDERED that 37 Motion for Summary Judgment is GRANTED IN PART and DENIED IN PART as set forth in this Decision and Order. The parties are advised that in all further proceedings, they should be prepared to fully brief whether the legitimate Penological interest or the compelling government interest test should be applied to this case. Signed by Judge Hurd on 1/20/11.{order served via regular mail on all non−ecf parties}(nas) (Entered: 01/20/2011)

original_case_data.name: Kalwasinski v. Maxymillian
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: Muslim inmate at the Central New York Psychiatric Center who alleged that the facility violated his right to freely exercise his religion.
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
original_case_data.summary:
On February 20, 2009, a Muslim prisoner at the Central New York Psychiatric Center filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York. The pro se plaintiff sued the Director of the Sex Offender Treatment Program, the New York State Office of Health Commissioner, and the Executive Director of the Central New York Psychiatric Center under 42 U.S.C. §1983. The plaintiff sought injunctive and monetary relief, claiming violations of the First Amendment Free Exercise Clause, the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clauses, and the Eighth Amendment prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment. The plaintiff alleged that his facility, the Central New York Psychiatric Center (CNYPC) did not allow him to properly participate in Al-Jumu’ah prayer services, forced him to attend classes on Fridays in violation of Muslim practice, and denied him food in compliance with Halal.

On March 17, 2010, the plaintiff moved for summary judgment. He argued there was clear evidence the CNYPC misunderstood the requirements for Al-Jumu’ah prayer and in doing so deprived him of Free Exercise. On April 14, 2010, the defendants filed a cross-motion for summary judgment, arguing (1) that the reason Al-Jumu’ah prayer has not been provided is that there are no Imams in the area who are available to facilitate, (2) the food offered in the cafeteria allows those following a Halal diet to sustain good health without violating their dietary laws, and (3) the utensils are sufficiently washed so as to be in compliance with Halal.

On December 23, 2010, Magistrate Judge George Lowe issued a report and recommendation to Judge David Hurd, (2010 WL 5620908), which Judge Hurd then adopted in full on January 20, 2011. Judge Hurd denied the plaintiff’s motion for summary judgment while granting in part and denying in part the defendant’s motion for summary judgment. The surviving claims included the Free Exercise and Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act claims regarding the lack of Al-Jumu’ah services, the lack of a Halal-compliant menu, the denial of access to sacred food on religious holidays, and the requirement to attend classes on Fridays. The court dismissed the Free Exercise claims regarding bowls, utensils, and serving fish on Fridays; the Establishment Clause claim regarding serving fish on Fridays; the Due Process Claims; the Eighth Amendment claim; and the claim against the New York State Office of Health Commissioner. 2011 WL 195648.

After the appointment of pro bono counsel on September 29, 2011, parties moved to settle the lawsuit. On November 14, 2011, the parties consented to have Magistrate Judge Lowe oversee the negotiations and final resolution of the case. On February 7, 2012, the parties settled and Magistrate Judge Lowe signed off on the settlement the next day. According to the settlement, the defendants would pay the plaintiff $15,000, which included all damages, costs, and attorney’s fees, and the defendants further agreed to have a Halal menu in place and retain an Imam to lead Al-Jumu’ah services on Fridays. As no action has been taken on this case since, it is likely this case is closed.
original_case_data.summary_short: On February 20, 2009, a Muslim prisoner at the Central New York Psychiatric Center filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York. The pro se plaintiff sued affiliates of CNYPC under 42 U.S.C. §1983 for various constitutional violations which he alleged denied him of freedom to freely practice his faith. After both parties were denied summary judgment, the parties settled on February 7, 2012, agreeing that the defendants would take measures to ensure the inmate’s religious requirements were met.

0.text:
On February 20, 2009, a Muslim prisoner at the Central New York Psychiatric Center filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York. The pro se plaintiff sued the Director of the Sex Offender Treatment Program, the New York State Office of Health Commissioner, and the Executive Director of the Central New York Psychiatric Center under 42 U.S.C. §1983. The plaintiff sought injunctive and monetary relief, claiming violations of the First Amendment Free Exercise Clause, the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clauses, and the Eighth Amendment prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment. The plaintiff alleged that his facility, the Central New York Psychiatric Center (CNYPC) did not allow him to properly participate in Al-Jumu’ah prayer services, forced him to attend classes on Fridays in violation of Muslim practice, and denied him food in compliance with Halal.

On March 17, 2010, the plaintiff moved for summary judgment. He argued there was clear evidence the CNYPC misunderstood the requirements for Al-Jumu’ah prayer and in doing so deprived him of Free Exercise. On April 14, 2010, the defendants filed a cross-motion for summary judgment, arguing (1) that the reason Al-Jumu’ah prayer has not been provided is that there are no Imams in the area who are available to facilitate, (2) the food offered in the cafeteria allows those following a Halal diet to sustain good health without violating their dietary laws, and (3) the utensils are sufficiently washed so as to be in compliance with Halal.

Judge Hurd denied the plaintiff’s motion for summary judgment while granting in part and denying in part the defendant’s motion for summary judgment. The surviving claims included the Free Exercise and Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act claims regarding the lack of Al-Jumu’ah services, the lack of a Halal-compliant menu, the denial of access to sacred food on religious holidays, and the requirement to attend classes on Fridays. The court dismissed the Free Exercise claims regarding bowls, utensils, and serving fish on Fridays; the Establishment Clause claim regarding serving fish on Fridays; the Due Process Claims; the Eighth Amendment claim; and the claim against the New York State Office of Health Commissioner. 2011 WL 195648.

After the appointment of pro bono counsel on September 29, 2011, parties moved to settle the lawsuit. On November 14, 2011, the parties consented to have Magistrate Judge Lowe oversee the negotiations and final resolution of the case. On February 7, 2012, the parties settled and Magistrate Judge Lowe signed off on the settlement the next day. According to the settlement, the defendants would pay the plaintiff $15,000, which included all damages, costs, and attorney’s fees, and the defendants further agreed to have a Halal menu in place and retain an Imam to lead Al-Jumu’ah services on Fridays. As no action has been taken on this case since, it is likely this case is closed.

1.transformed_text:
On February 20, 2009, a pro se Muslim prisoner at the Central New York Psychiatric Center initiated a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York against the Director of the Sex Offender Treatment Program, the New York State Office of Health Commissioner, and the Executive Director of the Central New York Psychiatric Center under 42 U.S.C. §1983. The plaintiff sought both injunctive and monetary relief, asserting claims for violations of the First Amendment Free Exercise Clause, the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clauses, and the Eighth Amendment prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment. His allegations focused on the Central New York Psychiatric Center (CNYPC)'s failure to permit proper participation in Al-Jumu’ah prayer services, its requirement that he attend classes on Fridays in violation of Muslim practice, and its denial of food compliant with Halal dietary laws.

The plaintiff subsequently moved for summary judgment, arguing that clear evidence demonstrated CNYPC's misunderstanding of Al-Jumu’ah prayer requirements and its resultant deprivation of his Free Exercise rights. In response, the defendants filed a cross-motion for summary judgment, asserting that Al-Jumu’ah prayer was unavailable due to a lack of available local Imams, that the cafeteria food adequately accommodated Halal diets without violating religious dietary laws, and that all utensils were sufficiently washed to ensure Halal compliance.

Magistrate Judge George Lowe issued a report and recommendation to Judge David Hurd, which Judge Hurd adopted in full on January 20, 2011 (2010 WL 5620908; 2011 WL 195648). Judge Hurd denied the plaintiff’s motion for summary judgment while granting in part and denying in part the defendants’ cross-motion. Surviving claims included Free Exercise and Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act claims concerning the lack of Al-Jumu’ah services, absence of a Halal-compliant menu, denial of access to sacred food on religious holidays, and the mandatory attendance at Friday classes. The court dismissed Free Exercise claims regarding bowls, utensils, and serving fish on Fridays; the Establishment Clause claim regarding serving fish on Fridays; the Due Process Claims; the Eighth Amendment claim; and the claim against the New York State Office of Health Commissioner.

Following the appointment of pro bono counsel, the parties moved to settle the lawsuit and consented to Magistrate Judge Lowe overseeing negotiations and final resolution. On February 7, 2012, the parties settled, with Magistrate Judge Lowe signing off the following day. The settlement stipulated defendants would pay the plaintiff $15,000, covering all damages, costs, and attorney’s fees, and further agreed to implement a Halal menu and retain an Imam to lead Al-Jumu’ah services on Fridays. No further action has been taken, indicating the case is likely closed.

2.transformed_text:
On February 20, 2009, a pro se Muslim prisoner at the Central New York Psychiatric Center commenced an action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York against the Director of the Sex Offender Treatment Program, the New York State Office of Health Commissioner, and the Executive Director of the Central New York Psychiatric Center. Proceeding under 42 U.S.C. §1983, the plaintiff sought injunctive and monetary relief, alleging violations of the First Amendment Free Exercise Clause, the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clauses, and the Eighth Amendment. His complaint asserted that the Central New York Psychiatric Center (CNYPC) failed to permit proper participation in Al-Jumu’ah prayer, mandated Friday class attendance contrary to Muslim practice, and denied Halal-compliant food.

Following cross-motions for summary judgment, Magistrate Judge George Lowe issued a report and recommendation, which Judge David Hurd adopted in full on January 20, 2011. The court denied the plaintiff’s motion for summary judgment and granted in part, denied in part, the defendants’ cross-motion. Surviving claims included those under the Free Exercise Clause and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA) concerning the lack of Al-Jumu’ah services, the absence of a Halal-compliant menu, the denial of access to sacred food on religious holidays, and the mandatory attendance at Friday classes. Dismissed claims encompassed Free Exercise allegations regarding bowls, utensils, and serving fish on Fridays; the Establishment Clause claim regarding serving fish on Fridays; the Due Process claims; the Eighth Amendment claim; and the claim against the New York State Office of Health Commissioner.

After pro bono counsel was appointed, the parties pursued settlement, consenting to Magistrate Judge Lowe’s oversight of negotiations and final resolution. On February 7, 2012, the parties reached a settlement, which Magistrate Judge Lowe approved the following day. The agreement stipulated the defendants would pay the plaintiff $15,000, encompassing all damages, costs, and attorney’s fees. Furthermore, the defendants committed to implementing a Halal menu and retaining an Imam to lead Al-Jumu’ah services on Fridays. No subsequent action has occurred, indicating the case’s probable closure.

On February 20, 2009, a Muslim prisoner at the Central New York Psychiatric Center filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York. The pro se plaintiff sued the Director of the Sex Offender Treatment Program, the New York State Office of Health Commissioner, and the Executive Director of the Central New York Psychiatric Center under 42 U.S.C. §1983. The plaintiff sought injunctive and monetary relief, claiming violations of the First Amendment Free Exercise Clause, the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clauses, and the Eighth Amendment prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment. The plaintiff alleged that his facility, the Central New York Psychiatric Center (CNYPC) did not allow him to properly participate in Al-Jumu’ah prayer services, forced him to attend classes on Fridays in violation of Muslim practice, and denied him food in compliance with Halal.

On March 17, 2010, the plaintiff moved for summary judgment. He argued there was clear evidence the CNYPC misunderstood the requirements for Al-Jumu’ah prayer and in doing so deprived him of Free Exercise. On April 14, 2010, the defendants filed a cross-motion for summary judgment, arguing (1) that the reason Al-Jumu’ah prayer has not been provided is that there are no Imams in the area who are available to facilitate, (2) the food offered in the cafeteria allows those following a Halal diet to sustain good health without violating their dietary laws, and (3) the utensils are sufficiently washed so as to be in compliance with Halal.

On December 23, 2010, Magistrate Judge George Lowe issued a report and recommendation to Judge David Hurd, (2010 WL 5620908), which Judge Hurd then adopted in full on January 20, 2011. Judge Hurd denied the plaintiff’s motion for summary judgment while granting in part and denying in part the defendant’s motion for summary judgment. The surviving claims included the Free Exercise and Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act claims regarding the lack of Al-Jumu’ah services, the lack of a Halal-compliant menu, the denial of access to sacred food on religious holidays, and the requirement to attend classes on Fridays. The court dismissed the Free Exercise claims regarding bowls, utensils, and serving fish on Fridays; the Establishment Clause claim regarding serving fish on Fridays; the Due Process Claims; the Eighth Amendment claim; and the claim against the New York State Office of Health Commissioner. 2011 WL 195648.

After the appointment of pro bono counsel on September 29, 2011, parties moved to settle the lawsuit. On November 14, 2011, the parties consented to have Magistrate Judge Lowe oversee the negotiations and final resolution of the case. On February 7, 2012, the parties settled and Magistrate Judge Lowe signed off on the settlement the next day. According to the settlement, the defendants would pay the plaintiff $15,000, which included all damages, costs, and attorney’s fees, and the defendants further agreed to have a Halal menu in place and retain an Imam to lead Al-Jumu’ah services on Fridays. As no action has been taken on this case since, it is likely this case is closed.

1.transformed_text:
On February 20, 2009, a Muslim prisoner at the Central New York Psychiatric Center filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of New York. The plaintiff, representing himself, sued the Director of the Sex Offender Treatment Program, the New York State Office of Health Commissioner, and the Executive Director of the Central New York Psychiatric Center under a federal civil rights law. The plaintiff asked the court for orders and money, claiming his rights were violated under the First Amendment (right to practice religion), the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments (right to fair treatment), and the Eighth Amendment (protection against cruel and unusual punishment). The plaintiff alleged that his facility, the Central New York Psychiatric Center (CNYPC), did not allow him to properly participate in Al-Jumu’ah prayer services, forced him to attend classes on Fridays in violation of Muslim practice, and denied him food that followed Halal dietary laws.

On March 17, 2010, the plaintiff asked the court to rule in his favor without a full trial. He argued there was clear evidence that the CNYPC misunderstood the requirements for Al-Jumu’ah prayer, which violated his right to practice his religion. On April 14, 2010, the defendants filed their own request for a ruling in their favor. They argued (1) that Al-Jumu’ah prayer wasn't provided because no Imams were available in the area to lead services, (2) the food offered in the cafeteria allowed those following a Halal diet to eat healthily without breaking their dietary laws, and (3) the utensils were cleaned well enough to meet Halal standards.

On December 23, 2010, Magistrate Judge George Lowe made a recommendation to Judge David Hurd, which Judge Hurd fully accepted on January 20, 2011. Judge Hurd rejected the plaintiff's request for a ruling in his favor. However, he partially granted and partially denied the defendants' request for a ruling in their favor. The claims that remained active included those related to his right to practice religion and claims under the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act. These claims concerned the lack of Al-Jumu’ah services, the absence of a Halal menu, being denied sacred food on religious holidays, and the requirement to attend classes on Fridays. The court dismissed (or threw out) other claims. These included the religious freedom claims about bowls, utensils, and serving fish on Fridays; the claim about the separation of church and state regarding serving fish on Fridays; the claims about fair treatment; the claim about cruel and unusual punishment; and the claim against the New York State Office of Health Commissioner.

After a lawyer was appointed to work for free (pro bono) on September 29, 2011, both sides moved to settle the lawsuit. On November 14, 2011, both sides agreed to have Magistrate Judge Lowe supervise the settlement discussions and the final agreement. On February 7, 2012, the parties reached a settlement, which Magistrate Judge Lowe approved the next day. Under the settlement, the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiff $15,000. This amount covered all money for harm, court costs, and legal fees. The defendants also agreed to provide a Halal menu and hire a religious leader (Imam) to lead Al-Jumu’ah services on Fridays. As no action has been taken on this case since, it is likely this case is closed.

Factual Consistency: YES

2.transformed_text:
On February 20, 2009, a Muslim prisoner at the Central New York Psychiatric Center filed a lawsuit in a federal court in New York. The prisoner, acting as his own lawyer, sued several officials, including the Director of the Sex Offender Treatment Program and the Executive Director of the Central New York Psychiatric Center. He brought the case under a federal civil rights law that allows people to sue government officials for violating their rights. He asked the court to order changes and pay him money, claiming his rights were violated. These rights included the First Amendment's guarantee of religious freedom, the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments' promise of fair treatment (known as 'due process'), and the Eighth Amendment's protection against cruel and unusual punishment. The prisoner claimed that his facility, the Central New York Psychiatric Center (CNYPC), did not allow him to properly participate in Al-Jumu’ah prayer services, forced him to attend classes on Fridays in violation of Muslim practice, and denied him food that followed Halal dietary laws.

On March 17, 2010, the prisoner asked the court to decide the case in his favor without a full trial, a request known as a "motion for summary judgment." He argued there was clear evidence that the CNYPC misunderstood the requirements for Al-Jumu’ah prayer, which violated his right to practice his religion. On April 14, 2010, the officials he sued filed their own request for a ruling in their favor. They argued (1) that Al-Jumu’ah prayer wasn't provided because no Imams were available in the area to lead services, (2) the food offered in the cafeteria allowed those following a Halal diet to eat healthily without breaking their dietary laws, and (3) the utensils were cleaned well enough to meet Halal standards.

On December 23, 2010, a lower-level judge, Magistrate Judge George Lowe, made a recommendation to the main judge, Judge David Hurd. Judge Hurd fully agreed with this recommendation on January 20, 2011. Judge Hurd denied the prisoner's request to rule in his favor. However, he partly approved and partly rejected the officials' request for a ruling in their favor. Some of the prisoner's claims were allowed to continue. These included those related to his right to practice religion, specifically under a law called the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA), which protects the religious freedom of people in institutions. These claims concerned the lack of Al-Jumu’ah services, the absence of a Halal menu, being denied sacred food on religious holidays, and the requirement to attend classes on Fridays. The court dismissed, or threw out, other claims. These dismissed claims included religious freedom complaints about bowls, utensils, and serving fish on Fridays; a claim about the separation of church and state regarding serving fish on Fridays; the claims about fair treatment; the claim about cruel and unusual punishment; and the claim against the New York State Office of Health Commissioner.

After a lawyer was appointed to work for free, or "pro bono," on September 29, 2011, both sides decided to try and settle the lawsuit. On November 14, 2011, both sides agreed to have Magistrate Judge Lowe oversee the settlement talks and the final agreement. On February 7, 2012, the parties reached a settlement, which Magistrate Judge Lowe approved the next day. Under the agreement, the officials agreed to pay the prisoner $15,000. This money covered damages, court costs, and legal fees. The officials also agreed to provide a Halal menu and hire a religious leader, an Imam, to lead Al-Jumu’ah services on Fridays. As no action has been taken on this case since, it is likely this case is closed.

4.transformed_text:
In 2009, a Muslim prisoner started a lawsuit. He was at a place called the Central New York Psychiatric Center. He sued some people in charge. These included the head of a program and the main boss of the center. He didn't have a lawyer at first.

He said they broke a federal law. This law lets people sue if their rights are taken away. He wanted the court to make changes. He also wanted money. He said his rights were broken. He said his rights to practice his religion were broken. He also said he wasn't treated fairly. And he said he was treated in a cruel way.

He claimed the center didn't let him pray properly. This was for a special Friday prayer called Al-Jumu’ah. He also said they made him go to classes on Fridays. This went against his Muslim beliefs. And he said they didn't give him Halal food.

Later, the prisoner asked the judge to decide the case without a full trial. He wanted the judge to rule in his favor right away. He said it was clear the center didn't understand his prayer needs. He said this broke his right to practice his religion.

The people he sued also asked the judge to rule in their favor. They said they couldn't find religious leaders for the prayers. They also said the food was fine for a Halal diet. And they said the dishes were clean enough for Halal rules.

Then, a judge named George Lowe gave his ideas to the main judge, Judge David Hurd. Judge Hurd agreed with him. Judge Hurd said no to the prisoner's request. But he partly agreed and partly disagreed with the officials' request.

Some of the prisoner's complaints could still go forward. These were about his right to practice his religion. This was under a special law that protects religious freedom for people in places like the center. These complaints were about not having Al-Jumu’ah prayers. They were also about not having a Halal food menu. He also said he didn't get special food on religious holidays. And he had to go to classes on Fridays.

The court threw out his other complaints. These included complaints about bowls, dishes, and fish on Fridays. He also complained about church and state being mixed up because of the fish. His complaints about fair treatment and cruel treatment were also thrown out. And a complaint against a health office was thrown out too.

Later, a lawyer started working for the prisoner for free. Then, both sides decided to try and solve the problem without more court fights. They agreed that Judge Lowe would help them talk and make a deal.

In 2012, they made a deal. Judge Lowe approved it. The officials agreed to pay the prisoner $15,000. This money was for his troubles, court costs, and lawyer fees. The officials also agreed to offer Halal food. And they agreed to hire a religious leader, called an Imam, for the Friday prayers. Nothing else has happened in this case. So it is probably finished.

Factual Consistency: YES

1.transformed_text:
In February 2009, a Muslim prisoner at the Central New York Psychiatric Center initiated a legal challenge, asserting that the facility's practices infringed upon his fundamental religious freedoms. Seeking both a change in policy and financial compensation, he claimed that the Central New York Psychiatric Center (CNYPC) prevented him from properly participating in Al-Jumu’ah prayer services, compelled him to attend classes on Fridays contrary to Muslim practice, and denied him food compliant with Halal dietary laws. This lawsuit was his attempt to rectify what he perceived as violations of his constitutional rights, particularly his right to free exercise of religion.

A year later, in March 2010, the prisoner sought a decisive victory without the need for a full trial, arguing that the evidence unequivocally showed the CNYPC's failure to respect his religious practices, particularly concerning Al-Jumu’ah prayer. The defendants, in turn, countered in April 2010 with their own request for a judgment in their favor, aiming to dismiss the case by explaining their actions. They contended that the lack of Al-Jumu’ah services was due to the unavailability of Imams, that their cafeteria food adequately met Halal dietary needs, and that their utensils were properly maintained, thereby asserting their compliance with religious requirements.

The court's decision in early 2011 marked a pivotal moment, allowing certain core claims to move forward while dismissing others. While the prisoner's broad request for an immediate victory was denied, the court recognized the validity of his concerns regarding the absence of Al-Jumu’ah services, the lack of a Halal-compliant menu, the denial of sacred food on religious holidays, and the mandatory Friday classes. This ruling narrowed the scope of the dispute, focusing the legal battle on the most significant alleged infringements of his religious freedom.

With the assistance of newly appointed counsel, the parties ultimately sought to resolve the dispute outside of further litigation. This strategic move towards negotiation, overseen by the court, aimed to achieve a mutually agreeable resolution, avoiding the uncertainties and costs of a full trial. In February 2012, a settlement was reached: the defendants agreed to pay the prisoner $15,000 and, crucially, committed to implementing a Halal menu and retaining an Imam to lead Al-Jumu’ah services on Fridays. This outcome brought the long-standing dispute to a close, securing significant accommodations for the prisoner's religious practices.
